X.T: Choux romanesco, Vache qui rit et intégrales curvilignes

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Andrei Broder
Ravi Kumar
Farzin Maghoul
Prabhakar Raghavan
Sridhar Rajagopalan
Raymie Stata
Andrew Tomkins
Janet Wiener
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Studying the Web topology with graph theories: the Web is a bowtie.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Albert-László Barabási
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A further Web analysis: the Web appears to be a network ruled by a power-law distribution.

X.T: Graph Identification and Privacy in Social Networks

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Lise Getoor
ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a high level description on algorithms used to identify several different (because of the data noise) nodes as referring the same entity, Lise Getoor speaks about how to use these algorithms in social network in order to infer private information.

X.T: The Church-Turing Thesis: Story and Recent Progress

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Yuri Gurevich
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The premises of Church-Turing thesis, the thesis itself and the current work on it (abstract state machines).

X.T: The Marriage of Fractals and Splines

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Ron Goldman
ARTICLE.COMMENT: After looking to analogies between fractals and Bézier curves, Ron Golgman explains how to combine them by using complex numbers in Bézier equations.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Peter Sanders
ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a quick presentation of the algorithm, Peter Sanders presents some current uses and some possible future improvements to more complex problems.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Yoav Freund
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yoav Freund presents the random projection trees algorithm used to extract the few intrinsic dimensions in a highly-constrained high-dimensional system.

X.T: Learning From Examples Using Quantum Annealing (Google Workshop on Quantum Biology)

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Hartmut Neven
ARTICLE.COMMENT: This talk spends more time on explaining that machine learning from samples is an optimization issue, than describing how the algorithm is implemented on D-Wave chip.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Chris Dixon
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trying to predict someone's tastes in a domain from the preferences of other persons having taste similarities in other domains.

X.T: Near-Optimal Parallel Join Processing in MapReduce

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mirek Riedewald
ARTICLE.COMMENT:
A very technical presentation of an algorithm to implement join models in a MapReduce framework (see also this paperhttp://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/mirek/papers/2011-SIGMOD-ParallelJoins.pdf
frPDF).

X.T: Turing Centennial Conference: Turing, Church, Gödel, Computability, Complexity and Randomization

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Michael Rabin
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The history of computer theory, unsolvability, complexity… by one mathematician who participated to it.

X.T: Demain : quel temps ? Un mathématicien en visite chez Chronos

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jean-Marc Deshouillers
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The presentation of some subjects more or less linked to time, but their presentation is very high level so you have to know about them beforehand and, and the connection between the subjects is unclear.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Henri Bacry
ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is a pity that, given the speaker, the level of the presentation is so low and the last part, which gets philosophical, could have been more interesting if it would have been better presented.

A presentation of Collatz conjecture.

BLIST.TITLE:
Rational trigonometry:
This is bullshit.
Wildberger claims to have invented a new way to handle trigonometry, but this is just a rather simple rewrite of things known for a long time.
This may amuse a teenager interested by playing with mathematics.

X.T: WildTrig0: An Invitation to Geometry: the WildTrig series

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Norman J. Wildberger
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The introduction of the series and some advertisement for his book. He explains that some reasoning can be wrong because based on what we see on a drawing. He does such reasoning in the following videos…

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Norman J. Wildberger
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A reminder of the trigonometry as it is commonly taught.

X.T: WildTrig2: Quadrance via Pythagoras and Archimedes

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Norman J. Wildberger
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The presentation of quadrance, Pythagoras' theorem, and triple quad formula.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Norman J. Wildberger
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The presentation of spread.

X.T: WildTrig4: Five main laws of rational trigonometry

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Norman J. Wildberger
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The demonstration of three new formulas: the spread law, the cross law, and the triple spread formula.

X.T: Historic 'Tile' Discovery Gives Math World A Big Jolt
X.ST: It's the first such find in 30 years.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A 15th pentagon which can tile a plane has been discovered using a computer program.
